subject: Re: Call of Cthulhu, now in modern HTML
msgSnippet: Thank you. Thank you very much. PDFs are great and all, but resizing is wonderful.
messageBody:
Thank you. Thank you very much. PDFs are great and all, but resizing is wonderful.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>
> I wanted to read the writings of Mr. Thurston, but I've never been a huge fan of reading things in PDF. To this end, I've converted (through copy/paste and some linebreak changes) tim_rice09's PDF into modern HTML/CSS, and have posted my work to <https://github.com/adiabatic/qs-literature>. The actual page you're probably interested in is <http://adiabatic.github.com/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/>.
>
> An excerpt from the README, pasted here:
>
> > This repository contains literature written in Quickscript, an alternate orthography for English.
> >
> > At this point the one thing youï¿½ll probably want to look at is The Call of Cthulhu, originally posted to the mailing list by tim_rice09. Itï¿½s set in a Unicode-enabled version of Kingsley, a Junior Quickscript font thanks to the magic of @font-face.
> >
> > This version has a number of changes to the posted PDF:
> >
> > ï¿½ Itï¿½s in HTML, not PDF, for easier changes
> > ï¿½ line lengths are shortened (the initial line is only 65 characters long instead of a whopping 97 in the original)
> > ï¿½ paragraphs are indented
> > ï¿½ thereï¿½s space between paragraphs
> > ï¿½ ï¿½" blahï¿½ has been changed to ï¿½"blahï¿½ in multiple places
>
> If you're interested in the mechanics of this, I/Github Pages use(s) Jekyll to convert Markdown-formatted text to HTML.
>
